Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story: I sat beside my husband on the couch, listening as he recounted his day. He didn’t seem upset, but I could tell he needed me to be present, to offer a listening ear and maybe a reassuring touch. I wanted to give him my full attention, to be the supportive wife he deserved. But my phone buzzed with a message from the pool—apparently, swimmers were slipping into the shallow end without a lifeguard watching. My mind raced. As a lifeguard, I was expected to enforce safety rules at all times, even off-shift if I was nearby. The thought of someone getting hurt because I wasn’t there gnawed at me. My husband looked at me, waiting for a response, and I felt the weight of both roles pressing down. I wanted to be there for him, but I also felt the pull of my responsibility to keep others safe. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which expectation I should meet first.
